George Lucas did not plan out the whole Star Wars trilogy ahead of time, and before The Empire Strikes Back came out, there was a Star Wars novel called Splinter of the Mind's Eye, which focused on Luke and Leia. The plan was to make this a low budget sequel, and Han Solo and Chewbacca were left out because Harrison Ford had not yet signed a contract to appear in any sequels. But because Star Wars proved very successful and Harrison Ford eventually did sign on for sequels, we got the big budget The Empire Strikes Back. That said, most people who make sequels know better than to make the sequel a musical if the original movie was not itself a musical. It is hard to imagine what could have led to such colossally bad decision making.

The film begins with a dark cartoon illustrating Arther‚Äôs grappling with the overwhelming shadow resulting from the many traumas he‚Äôs endured throughout his life that motivated him to ultimately commit six murders.
Joker, in contrast to Arther, signifies to the entire narrative and character structure the potential for Arther to finally garnish some positive feedback from a world where he‚Äôd only ever been abused or otherwise ignored.
In the first installment, we were taken- albeit horrifyingly willingly, if we‚Äôre being honest with ourselves- along with Joker to unleash a world of hurt on his victims in a storm of seemingly justifiable violence. I say ‚Äúseemingly‚Äù because while we all seemed to feel a sadistic release of angst at Joker‚Äôs dealing out vigilante justice upon the society who ‚Äúabandons you and treats you like trash‚Äù , the question we‚Äôre forced to confront in this installment is; can violence be justified?
The reason we‚Äôre confronted with this question is, quite unlike the first film, the world releases its seemingly justifiable violence back upon Arther, which will explain the terrible ratings and reviews we‚Äôre seeing pouring in for this film. Nobody wants to see the main character lose, and lose so badly.
The audience expected more of the same sadistic pleasure of watching a form of twisted justice doled out to characters who misbehave and mistreat poor Arther; having none of their backstories for what may have motivated them to be such undesirable humans.
In that regard, the audience does get the same film, but this time, they know the backstory of the film‚Äôs victim of violence, and rather than receiving sadistic pleasure from seeing terrible actions suffering consequences, we feel sympathy for the victim, and- understanding his history- lament the violence he suffers throughout. And his perpetrators feel justified in their treatment of him the way we‚Äôd felt justified of his treatment of the first film‚Äôs victims.
